countermeasure.name: Authorize AzCopy with Entra ID
countermeasure.desc:
1. Install AzCopy:
    • Visit the AzCopy documentation page to download and install the latest version of AzCopy for your operating system.
    • Follow the installation instructions specific to your OS to get AzCopy installed and configured on your machine.
  2. Set up Microsoft Entra ID (formerly Azure AD) Authentication:
    • Ensure you have the necessary permissions in Microsoft Entra ID to access the Azure Data Lake Storage.
    • Open your command-line interface and log in to AzCopy using your Microsoft Entra ID account by running the following command: 
      azcopy login
    • Follow the prompted instructions to authenticate, which typically involves opening a unique URL in your browser and entering a code provided by AzCopy.
  3. Configure Access Policies:
    • In the Azure portal, navigate to the Azure Data Lake Storage account you want to secure.
    • Under the 'Access control (IAM)' tab, ensure that the user or service principal has the necessary role assignments, such as 'Storage Blob Data Contributor' or a custom role granting the needed permissions.
  4. Transfer Data with AzCopy using Microsoft Entra ID:
    • Use AzCopy to transfer files to or from Azure Data Lake Storage by specifying the source and destination in the AzCopy command.
    • For downloading data, use: 
      azcopy copy "https://.dfs.core.windows.net/" ""
    • For uploading data, use: 
      azcopy copy "" "https://.dfs.core.windows.net/"
    • Ensure that each command runs successfully, leveraging your Microsoft Entra ID credentials for secure data transaction instead of SAS tokens.
  5. Audit Activity Logs:
    • Monitor your Azure Data Lake Storage account using Azure Monitor or Azure Sentinel for any unauthorized access or unusual activity.
    • Set alerts for specific activities or anomalies to ensure timely responses to potential security threats.

countermeasure.name: Manage ACLs using Azure Portal
countermeasure.desc:
Managing Access Control Lists (ACLs) for directories and files in Azure Data Lake Storage is an essential security practice that ensures only authorized users have access to your data. This step-by-step guide will help you manage ACLs using the Azure portal.

  1. Login to the Azure portal using your credentials.
  2. Navigate to your Azure Data Lake Storage account by using the search bar or by accessing it through the "Storage accounts" section.
  3. Once inside the Data Lake Storage account page, locate and click on the "Containers" option in the left-hand menu to view the list of containers available in your account.
  4. Open the specific container which contains the directory or file for which you want to manage ACLs.
  5. Inside the container, browse to the particular directory or file where you need to set or update the ACLs. Click on it to open the item.
  6. Click on the "Access control (IAM)" option available at the top menu to begin managing the ACLs.
  7. Here you can view the current ACL settings. To add a new ACL entry, click on the "Add" button.
  8. In the Add access control settings, select the type of entity (User, Group, or Service Principal) that you are granting access to.
    1. Enter the principal name (email or ID) of the user, group, or service principal.
    2. Define the permission levels (Read, Write, Execute) to govern access. Ensure you provide the minimum necessary permissions to follow the principle of least privilege.
  9. Review the changes you've made, ensuring they align with your organization's security policies, and then click "Apply" to set the new ACLs.

Repeat the process for any other files or directories as necessary to ensure comprehensive access controls are in place.

It's also advisable to periodically review and update ACL settings to adapt to any changes in your organization's user roles or data access requirements.

countermeasure.name: Use Blob and DFS endpoints with private endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of Azure Data Lake Storage, it is crucial to configure private endpoints for both the Blob and Azure Data Lake Storage (DFS) endpoints. This ensures that traffic to these services is restricted to your virtual network, reducing exposure to potential threats.

  1. Access the Azure Portal and navigate to the resource group that contains your Data Lake Storage account.
  2. Go to your Storage Account and select the Networking option under the Settings menu.
  3. In the Networking pane, click on Private endpoint connections.
  4. Select + Private endpoint to create a new private endpoint.
  5. In the Basics tab, provide the following information:
    1. Name: Enter a unique name for the private endpoint.
    2. Region: Choose the same region as your storage account.
  6. Proceed to the Resource tab and configure the following:
    1. Resource type: Set this to Microsoft.Storage/storageAccounts.
    2. Resource: Select the Data Lake Storage account that will use this endpoint.
    3. Target sub-resource:
      1. Create one private endpoint with Blob as the sub-resource.
      2. Create another private endpoint with DFS as the sub-resource.
  7. In the Networking tab, specify the Virtual Network and Subnet where the private endpoint will be connected.
  8. Finish creating the private endpoint by following through with the Summary and Review + create tabs. Verify the configuration and click Create.

Repeat the process to ensure that both Blob and DFS endpoints are configured with private endpoints to ensure comprehensive security and network isolation.

Verify the configuration by checking the Private endpoint connections in your Data Lake Storage account. Ensure that there are separate entries for Blob and DFS endpoints.

References

  • Azure Data Lake Storage Explorer

countermeasure.name: Use security groups for ACL assignments
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security and manageability of Azure Data Lake Storage through Azure Active Directory (AAD) integration, it is advisable to use Microsoft Entra (previously Azure AD) security groups as the principal in Access Control List (ACL) entries. This approach not only helps to avoid exceeding Azure platform limits but also simplifies identity and access management across your resources. Follow these steps to implement this security countermeasure:

  1. Create or Use Existing Microsoft Entra Security Groups
    • Navigate to the Azure Portal.
    • Go to Azure Active Directory from the services list.
    • In the AAD dashboard, select Groups and click New group if you wish to create a new security group. Otherwise, select an existing group.
    • Specify the group type as Security and fill in the required fields such as Group name, Description, and Membership type.
    • Click Create to establish the security group.
  2. Assign Users to Security Groups
    • Within Azure Active Directory, under Groups, select your newly created or chosen security group.
    • Select the Members tab, then click Add members.
    • Search and select the relevant users you wish to include in this security group.
    • Click Select followed by Save to update the group's membership.
  3. Assign Security Groups to ACLs in Azure Data Lake Storage
    • Go back to the Azure Portal and navigate to your Data Lake Storage account.
    • Locate the Data Storage section and access the container or folder you wish to set permissions for.
    • Click on Access control (IAM) and then proceed to the Role assignments tab.
    • Select Add role assignment and choose a relevant role, such as Storage Blob Data Contributor, depending on the level of access needed.
    • In the Select dialog box, choose Members and enter the name of the security group created earlier.
    • Review and confirm the assignment by clicking Save.
  4. Verify and Test Permissions
    • Ensure users within the security groups can access resources appropriately. Test permissions by attempting to access the storage data as a group member.
    • If permissions issues arise, return to the role assignments or group memberships to amend errors.

By following these steps, you streamline management by utilizing AAD security groups in ACL configurations. This not only efficiently uses identity capabilities but also ensures that platform limits associated with ACL entries are not exceeded.

References

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Excessive role assignments or ACL entries
threat.desc:
General threat description
Exceeding the platform's limitations for role assignments or ACL entries may result in difficulties in managing permissions efficiently and securely within the Azure environment.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Users or administrators who unknowingly or accidentally configure permissions excessively, as well as automated scripts or applications that modify ACLs beyond recommended limits.
Impacts
Potential for security vulnerabilities due to mismanaged permissions, reduced system performance, and increased complexity in access management.
Example Attack Scenarios
An administrator mistakenly assigns excessive roles to users thinking it will cover all necessary permissions, leading to inadvertent access by unauthorized personnel, or a script that auto-configures ACL entries without checks ends up exceeding limits, resulting in failed access control processes.

threat.name: Inefficient authorization management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper authorization configurations could grant unintended access to storage accounts, putting sensitive data integrity at risk.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit misconfigured access policies or credentials to gain unauthorized access to perform operations on storage accounts.
Impacts
The compromise of data integrity could result in the alteration or unauthorized deletion of critical data, leading to potential data loss and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers a misconfigured storage account with overly permissive access settings, allowing them to alter or delete stored data without proper authorization checks.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Security risks due to inadequate encryption
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper encryption, sensitive data might be exposed to interception and unauthorized access in storage accounts.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers might intercept data during transmission or gain access to unprotected data in storage.
Impacts
Sensitive data may be compromised, leading to data breaches and potential legal consequences.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker intercepts data being transferred to the storage account, or accesses data stored without encryption due to configuration oversight.

threat.name: Unauthorized data access through ACL misconfiguration
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfigured or insufficient access control list settings in storage systems can result in unauthorized access to sensitive data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
External attackers or malicious insiders exploiting weak ACL settings to gain access to data.
Impacts
Potential data breaches, unauthorized data exposure, and compliance violations, possibly leading to financial and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies a storage account with lax ACL settings and accesses sensitive customer data; an insider changes ACL configurations to access restricted areas of the system without detection.

Consider the following common use cases: - Requiring multi-factor authentication for users with administrative roles - Requiring multi-factor authentication for Azure management tasks - Blocking sign-ins for users attempting to use legacy authentication protocols - Requiring trusted locations for Azure AD Multi-Factor Authentication registration - Blocking or granting access from specific locations - Blocking risky sign-in behaviors - Requiring organization-managed devices for specific applications
Note: Granular authentication session management controls can also be implemented through Azure AD conditional access policies such as sign-in frequency and persistent browser session.

countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control your encryption keys life cycle, including key generation, distribution, and storage. Rotate and revoke your keys in Azure Key Vault and your service based on the defined schedule and when there is a key retirement or compromise. Require a certain cryptographic type and minimum key size when generating keys.
When there is a need to use customer-managed key (CMK) in the workload services or applications, ensure you follow the best practices: - Use a key hierarchy to generate a separate data encryption key (DEK) with your key encryption key (KEK) in your key vault. - Ensure keys are registered with Azure Key Vault and implemented via key IDs in each service or application.
To maximize the key material lifetime and portability, bring your own key (BYOK) to the services (i.e., importing HSM-protected keys from your on-premises HSMs into Azure Key Vault). Follow the recommended guideline to perform the key generation and key transfer.
Note: Refer to the below for the FIPS 140-2 level for Azure Key Vault types and FIPS compliance/validation level. - Software-protected keys in vaults (Premium & Standard SKUs): FIPS 140-2 Level 1 - HSM-protected keys in vaults (Premium SKU): FIPS 140-2 Level 2 - HSM-protected keys in Managed HSM: FIPS 140-2 Level 3 Azure Key Vault Premium uses a shared HSM infrastructure in the backend. Azure Key Vault Managed HSM uses dedicated, confidential service endpoints with a dedicated HSM for when you need a higher level of key security.

usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Pre-installed ClamAV can be used to bypass malware detection
threat.desc:
General threat description
Installing ClamAV may pose a threat to system security if not properly configured and maintained.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may exploit misconfigurations or vulnerabilities in ClamAV to launch malware or exploit attacks against the compute instance. Attack vectors may include unauthorized access to ClamAV's signature databases or exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities in ClamAV software.
Impacts
The impacts of a misconfigured or compromised ClamAV instance may include the introduction of malware into the system, unauthorized access to sensitive information, and disruption of normal system operations.
Example Attack Scenarios
A threat actor exploits a known vulnerability in a specific version of ClamAV to gain unauthorized access to the compute instance and install malicious software. This software then exfiltrates sensitive data from the system, causing a data breach and potential financial and reputational damage to the organization.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure

threat.name: Unauthorized access to customer-managed encryption keys and data exfiltration
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat of unauthorized access to sensitive data at rest in cloud environments where encryption using customer-managed keys is not implemented can lead to data exposure and potential regulatory non-compliance.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized third-party applications. Attack vectors may involve unauthorized access to storage resources, exploitation of vulnerabilities, or misconfiguration leading to unauthorized data access.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat could include unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data, regulatory non-compliance, reputational damage, and financial loss due to potential fines or legal actions.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to the storage account and exfiltrates sensitive data stored in its unencrypted form. This data breach results in regulatory non-compliance and reputational damage to the organization. Alternatively, a malicious insider abuses their privileges to access and extract sensitive data from the storage resources, circumventing existing controls and leading to potential misuse of the information.

threat.name: Improper storage and handling of credentials and secrets
threat.desc:
General threat description
Storing secrets and credentials in code or configuration files presents a security risk, as unauthorized access or exposure of these credentials can lead to data breaches, unauthorized access, and potential compromise of sensitive information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
The threat agents or attack vectors for this threat include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized users who gain access to the code or configuration files. Attack vectors can include unauthorized access to version control systems, unauthorized viewing of configuration files, or exploiting vulnerabilities in the application code.
Impacts
The potential impacts of unauthorized access to embedded secrets and credentials include data breaches, unauthorized system access, compromised sensitive information, and potential compliance violations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the source code repository of an application and identifies embedded credentials. By extracting these credentials, the attacker gains unauthorized access to critical systems or sensitive data, leading to a data breach and potential reputational damage for the organization.

threat.name: Unauthorized configuration changes detected in Azure resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfigured cloud resources can lead to security vulnerabilities, unauthorized access, data breaches, and compliance violations. Threat actors may leverage misconfigurations to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data, disrupt services, or conduct other malicious activities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents, such as malicious hackers, insider threats, and automated bots, may exploit misconfigured Azure resources to gain unauthorized access, exfiltrate data, tamper with configurations, or disrupt services. Attack vectors include exploiting weak access controls, unsecured network configurations, and misconfigured security settings.
Impacts
The impacts of misconfigured Azure resources include unauthorized access, data leaks, service disruptions, regulatory non-compliance, financial loss, reputational damage, and legal consequences. Additionally, misconfigured resources can lead to exploitation of vulnerabilities, lateral movement within the cloud environment, and compromise of sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies a misconfigured storage account in Azure with overly permissive access control settings. The attacker exploits this misconfiguration to exfiltrate sensitive data stored within the storage account, leading to a data breach. Additionally, the attacker may modify or delete critical data, causing operational disruption and financial loss for the organization.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

weakness.name: CWE-923

countermeasure.name: Separate and limit highly privileged/administrative users
countermeasure.desc:
You must secure all roles with direct or indirect administrative access to Azure hosted resources.
Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Azure's default identity and access management service. The most critical built-in roles in Azure AD are Global Administrator and Privileged Role Administrator, because users assigned to these two roles can delegate administrator roles. With these privileges, users can directly or indirectly read and modify every resource in your Azure environment: - Global Administrator / Company Administrator: Users with this role have access to all administrative features in Azure AD as well as services that use Azure AD identities. - Privileged Role Administrator: Users with this role can manage role assignments in Azure AD, as well as within Azure AD Privileged Identity Management (PIM). In addition, this role allows management of all aspects of PIM and administrative units.
Outside of Azure AD, Azure has built-in roles that can be critical for privileged access at the resource level. - Owner: Grants full access to manage all resources, including the ability to assign roles in Azure RBAC. - Contributor: Grants full access to manage all resources, but does not allow you to assign roles in Azure RBAC, manage assignments in Azure Blueprints, or share image galleries. - User Access Administrator: Lets you manage user access to Azure resources. Note: You may have other critical roles that need to be governed if you use custom roles in the Azure AD level or resource level with certain privileged permissions assigned.
In addition, users with the following three roles in Azure Enterprise Agreement (EA) portal should also be restricted as they can be used to directly or indirectly manage Azure subscriptions. - Account Owner: Users with this role can manage subscriptions, including the creation and deletion of subscriptions. - Enterprise Administrator: Users assigned with this role can manage (EA) portal users. - Department Administrator: Users assigned with this role can change account owners within the department.
Lastly, ensure that you also restrict privileged accounts in other management, identity, and security systems that have administrative access to your business-critical assets, such as Active Directory Domain Controllers (DCs), security tools, and system management tools with agents installed on business-critical systems. Attackers who compromise these management and security systems can immediately weaponize them to compromise business critical assets.

countermeasure.name: Use a secure key management process
countermeasure.desc:
Use Azure Key Vault to create and control your encryption keys life cycle, including key generation, distribution, and storage. Rotate and revoke your keys in Azure Key Vault and your service based on the defined schedule and when there is a key retirement or compromise. Require a certain cryptographic type and minimum key size when generating keys.
When there is a need to use customer-managed key (CMK) in the workload services or applications, ensure you follow the best practices: - Use a key hierarchy to generate a separate data encryption key (DEK) with your key encryption key (KEK) in your key vault. - Ensure keys are registered with Azure Key Vault and implemented via key IDs in each service or application.
To maximize the key material lifetime and portability, bring your own key (BYOK) to the services (i.e., importing HSM-protected keys from your on-premises HSMs into Azure Key Vault). Follow the recommended guideline to perform the key generation and key transfer.
Note: Refer to the below for the FIPS 140-2 level for Azure Key Vault types and FIPS compliance/validation level. - Software-protected keys in vaults (Premium & Standard SKUs): FIPS 140-2 Level 1 - HSM-protected keys in vaults (Premium SKU): FIPS 140-2 Level 2 - HSM-protected keys in Managed HSM: FIPS 140-2 Level 3 Azure Key Vault Premium uses a shared HSM infrastructure in the backend. Azure Key Vault Managed HSM uses dedicated, confidential service endpoints with a dedicated HSM for when you need a higher level of key security.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors could exploit misconfigured systems, unpatched software, or unsecured network connections to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data or compromise the integrity of the system. 
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include unauthorized access to sensitive information, data breaches, disruption of services, financial losses, and damage to the organization's reputation. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could exploit a misconfigured security feature to gain unauthorized access to a sensitive database, exfiltrate valuable data, and potentially sell it on the dark web. countermeasure.name: Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for a User Profile component adds an essential layer of security by requiring users to provide two or more verification factors to gain access or perform specific actions. This reduces the risk of unauthorized access resulting from compromised credentials. Heres a step-by-step guide to implementing MFA:

Step 1: Choose Your MFA Methods

  • Select at least two different authentication factors from the following categories: something the user knows (password or PIN), something the user has (a mobile device, security token, or smart card), and something the user is (biometric verification like fingerprints or facial recognition).
  • Consider user experience and security needs when selecting MFA methods. For instance, SMS-based codes and authentication apps are popular choices for their balance of convenience and security.

Step 2: Integrate MFA into Your User Profile System

  • Use a reputable MFA library or service that is compatible with your development stack. Many cloud providers and security companies offer MFA services that can be easily integrated into existing systems.
  • Configure the MFA service or library according to the provider's documentation, ensuring it is set up to manage the authentication factors you've chosen.

Step 3: Update Authentication Flows

  • Modify the login and sensitive action workflows to include MFA. After entering their standard credentials (e.g., username and password), prompt users to complete an additional authentication step.
  • Implement logic to handle different MFA methods, such as sending a code via SMS or email, generating time-based codes through an app, or prompting for biometric verification.

Step 4: Securely Store MFA Credentials

  • Store MFA secret keys or tokens securely, using encryption and secure access controls. Ensure they are protected both in transit and at rest.
  • Follow best practices for any biometric data, ensuring it is stored in a manner that respects privacy and is secure against unauthorized access.

Step 5: Provide User Instructions and Support

  • Guide users through setting up MFA for their profiles. Offer clear instructions on activating and using their chosen authentication factors.
  • Offer support for users who have issues with MFA, including options to reset or change their authentication factors if they lose access to their device or encounter other problems.

Step 6: Test and Monitor

  • Thoroughly test the MFA implementation across different devices and scenarios to ensure reliability and usability.
  • Monitor for failed authentication attempts and investigate any anomalies that could indicate attempted unauthorized access.

Best Practices and Considerations

  • Fallback options: Provide alternatives in case the primary MFA method fails (e.g., backup codes or secondary verification methods).
  • Rate limiting: Implement rate limiting for MFA attempts to prevent brute force attacks.
  • Compliance: Ensure your MFA implementation complies with relevant regulations and standards, such as GDPR for privacy or PCI DSS for payment information.
  • User education: Educate your users on the importance of MFA and how to securely manage their authentication factors.

By following these steps and considerations, developers can effectively implement MFA for the User Profile component, significantly enhancing the security posture of the application.

countermeasure.name: Implement secure session management
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard the "User Profile" software component through secure session management, follow these targeted, actionable steps. Secure session management is crucial to prevent unauthorized access and protect user data. This guidance focuses on creating and managing sessions securely, with an emphasis on web applications.

Step 1: Generate Secure Session Identifiers

  1. Use Secure, Random Values: Ensure session identifiers (IDs) are generated using a cryptographically secure random number generator.
  2. Maintain Sufficient Length: Session IDs should be long enough to prevent brute force attacks. Aim for at least 128 bits of entropy.

Step 2: Use HTTPS for All Transactions

  1. Implement HTTPS: Ensure that all communication between the client and server is encrypted using HTTPS to protect the session ID and other sensitive data in transit.
  2. Secure Cookies: Set the Secure attribute on all cookies to ensure they are only sent over encrypted connections.

Step 3: Proper Session Expiration

  1. Set Timeout Limits: Implement automatic session expiration. Sessions should time out after a predefined period of inactivity (e.g., 15 to 30 minutes).
  2. Clear Session at Logout: Ensure that sessions are completely invalidated and cleared from the server upon user logout.

Step 4: Implement Cookie Attributes Correctly

  1. HttpOnly Attribute: Set the HttpOnly attribute for cookies to prevent access to the session cookie via client-side scripts, mitigating the risk of cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.
  2. SameSite Attribute: Use the SameSite attribute to restrict how cookies are sent with cross-site requests, providing some protection against cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks.

Step 5: Validate Session ID for Every Request

  1. Verify Sessions: Check the validity of the session ID for every request to ensure it matches the user and hasn't been tampered with.
  2. Regenerate Session IDs: Upon login, logout, and during regular intervals, regenerate session IDs to mitigate session fixation attacks.

Step 6: Store Sessions Securely

  1. Use Server-Side Storage: Preferably store session data on the server side where possible, using a secure and scalable session management system.
  2. Encrypt Sensitive Data: If any sensitive information must be stored within the session, ensure it is encrypted.

Good Security Practices

  • Monitor and Log Session Activities: Implement monitoring to detect unusual session patterns or behaviors that may indicate an attack.
  • Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Protection: Sanitize user input and implement content security policies to prevent XSS attacks, which can compromise session security.
  • Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Protection: Use anti-CSRF tokens in forms and requests to ensure that state-changing requests originate from your application.
  • Regular Security Audits: Conduct regular security reviews and penetration testing focused on session management to identify and rectify potential vulnerabilities.

By following these steps, developers can significantly enhance the security of user sessions within their applications, protecting both user data and the integrity of the application itself.

countermeasure.name: Sanitize all input to avoid injection attacks
countermeasure.desc:
When developing software, particularly components like user profiles that accept user-generated input, its crucial to mitigate the risk of injection attacks. Injection attacks occur when attackers input malicious data that the system interprets and executes as commands. This can lead to unauthorized access, data leaks, and system compromise. To prevent such vulnerabilities, follow these steps to sanitize inputs effectively:

Validate Input Strictly:

  • Enforce strict type, length, and format for all inputs. Use regular expressions to validate string inputs against expected patterns.
  • Implement client-side validation for immediate feedback but always perform server-side validation as the primary defense mechanism.

Employ Parameterized Queries:

  • Use parameterized queries or prepared statements for database access. This ensures that input is treated only as data and not executable code, effectively neutralizing SQL injection threats.

Utilize Content Security Policy (CSP):

  • Implement a Content Security Policy as an additional layer of protection against Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. CSP can restrict how and where content can be loaded, preventing the execution of unauthorized scripts.

Encode Data:

  • Before displaying user input on web pages or in application interfaces, encode the data to escape any characters that could be interpreted as executable code. This is especially crucial for HTML, JavaScript, and SQL outputs.

Leverage Security Libraries and Frameworks:

  • Take advantage of existing security libraries and frameworks that offer input sanitization and validation functions. These are often well-tested and updated to defend against emerging threats.

Conduct Regular Security Audits:

  • Regularly review and audit your codebase and dependencies for vulnerabilities. Automated security scanning tools can identify potential injection flaws in your application.

Educate and Train Developers:

  • Ensure that all team members are aware of the risks associated with injection attacks and understand the importance of input sanitization. Promote a culture of security within the development team.

Test for Vulnerabilities:

  • Implement comprehensive testing strategies, including static analysis, dynamic analysis, and penetration testing, to uncover and mitigate injection vulnerabilities.

By adhering to these guidelines and adopting a proactive security posture, developers can significantly reduce the risk of injection attacks on user profile components and other vulnerable parts of their applications. Always stay informed about the latest security best practices and vulnerabilities to maintain the robustness of your security measures.

threat.name: Attackers take advantage of exposed sensitive data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Exposed sensitive data refers to personal or confidential information that becomes accessible to unauthorized individuals due to inadequate protection measures. In the context of a User Profile component, this could include names, email addresses, passwords, payment information, or any personal data that users submit. Exposure can occur through various means, such as improper access controls, lack of encryption, or inadvertent leaks via logs or error messages.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Includes cybercriminals aiming for identity theft or financial gain, competitors seeking confidential information, and insiders with malicious intent or negligence.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Insecure Direct Object References (IDOR): Attackers manipulate direct references to access other users' data.
    • Insufficient Data Encryption: Data transmitted or stored without encryption can be intercepted or accessed.
    • Misconfigured Databases or Servers: Incorrect configurations can expose data through unintended public access points.
    • Caching Mechanisms: Sensitive information stored in cache without proper access controls could be leaked.

Impacts

  • Identity Theft: Exposed personal details can lead to identity theft, significantly impacting users' lives.
  • Financial Loss: Exposure of payment information can lead to unauthorized transactions and financial losses for users.
  • Reputation Damage: Organizations responsible for data breaches face severe reputational damage, eroding trust among users and partners.
  • Legal and Compliance Violations: Breaches involving sensitive data can result in legal penalties, fines, and failure to comply with data protection regulations like GDPR or HIPAA.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. IDOR Exploit: An attacker discovers that the user profile edit function is vulnerable to IDOR. By changing the user ID in the URL, they gain access to and modify other users' profiles, harvesting sensitive data.
  2. Database Misconfiguration: A database containing user profiles is mistakenly configured to allow public access. Sensitive user data is indexed by search engines, making it easily accessible to anyone performing a simple search.
  3. Insecure API Endpoint: An API endpoint designed to fetch user profile details does not properly verify the requestor's identity or permissions. Attackers exploit this by crafting requests that retrieve personal information of all users.
  4. Error Message Leakage: A coding error in the user profile management system leads to detailed error messages being displayed, including sensitive database information. Attackers use this information to further exploit the system.

To mitigate the risk of exposed sensitive data:

  • Implement Strict Access Controls: Ensure that only authenticated and authorized users can access or modify user profile data.
  • Encrypt Sensitive Data: Use strong encryption for storing and transmitting user data.
  • Regularly Audit and Configure Security Settings: Regularly review and update configurations for databases, servers, and applications to prevent accidental exposure.
  • Data Minimization: Collect and retain only the minimum necessary personal information for users.
  • Error Handling: Implement secure error handling practices that do not expose sensitive information in logs or error messages.
  • Educate Employees: Provide training on data protection best practices and the importance of maintaining the confidentiality of user data.

By addressing these aspects, organizations can significantly reduce the risk associated with the exposure of sensitive data within user profile components.

threat.name: Attackers exploit flaws in access control systems
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Access control systems are designed to restrict unauthorized users from performing certain actions within a software system, typically through mechanisms like authentication and authorization. Flaws in these systems can arise from misconfigurations, software vulnerabilities, or inadequate security policies, potentially allowing attackers to bypass security measures. This can lead to unauthorized access to or manipulation of user profiles and associated data, which may contain sensitive personal information, preferences, and security settings.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents include:

  1. Cybercriminals: Seeking financial gain through data theft, fraud, or selling access.
  2. Disgruntled Employees: Internal actors who exploit their knowledge of the system's weaknesses.
  3. Competitors: Looking to gain a competitive edge by stealing confidential data.
  4. Hacktivists or State-Sponsored Actors: Targeting systems for political, ideological, or strategic reasons.

Attack Vectors involve:

  1. Privilege Escalation: Exploiting vulnerabilities to gain elevated access rights.
  2. Authorization Bypass: Manipulating the system to access functions or data without proper authorization.
  3. Credential Stuffing: Using breached username and password pairs to gain unauthorized access.
  4. Session Hijacking: Exploiting flaws in session management to take over a user's legitimate session.

Impacts

  1. Data Breach: Unauthorized access to user profiles can lead to the exposure of sensitive personal and financial information.
  2. Identity Theft: Attackers can use stolen data for impersonation and fraud.
  3. Loss of Integrity: Modification of user data can lead to incorrect or malicious actions being taken on behalf of the user.
  4. Reputational Damage: Breaches can severely damage an organization's reputation, leading to loss of trust and customers.
  5. Regulatory and Legal Consequences: Non-compliance with data protection laws can result in fines and legal action.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a flaw in the application's role-based access control mechanism that allows unauthorized API calls to be made without proper role verification. The attacker exploits this to access and export user profiles en masse.

Scenario 2: Through credential stuffing, an attacker gains access to a user's profile with administrative privileges due to reused passwords from another breached service. The attacker then alters access controls to grant unauthorized access to other attackers.

Scenario 3: A session management vulnerability allows an attacker to hijack an authenticated user's session token. The attacker uses this token to impersonate the user, accessing and manipulating the user's profile information without detection.

To mitigate these threats, it's crucial to implement robust access control mechanisms, regularly update and patch software components, employ multi-factor authentication, conduct regular security audits and vulnerability assessments, and educate users about security best practices.

threat.name: Attackers inject malicious code into systems by exploiting security weaknesses
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

This threat involves attackers injecting malicious code into systems by exploiting security weaknesses in the software component handling user profiles. The injected code could range from scripts designed to steal data to commands that compromise the integrity or availability of the system. This vulnerability often stems from insufficient input validation, allowing attackers to insert and execute unauthorized code within the system's operational context.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

The primary threat agents are cyber attackers ranging from individual hackers to organized cybercrime groups. They exploit vulnerabilities in the software's input validation processes, using attack vectors such as crafted inputs submitted through forms, URLs, or any interface that accepts user data. The attackers might also employ social engineering techniques to trick users into executing the malicious code themselves.

Impacts:

The impacts of such an attack can be severe and multifaceted, including:

  • Unauthorized access to or theft of sensitive user data, potentially leading to identity theft or financial fraud.
  • Compromise of system integrity, allowing attackers to alter or delete critical data.
  • Disruption of service, which could degrade the user experience or completely disable the service.
  • Damage to the organizations reputation, leading to loss of trust among users and financial losses.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a vulnerability in the user profile component of a web application that fails to properly sanitize input. The attacker crafts a malicious script that is executed when a user views their profile. This script steals the user's session cookie and sends it to the attacker, allowing them to hijack the user's session.

Scenario 2: In another instance, the attacker injects a SQL command into a poorly secured user input field related to the user profile. This injection manipulates the backend database to grant the attacker unauthorized access to other users' profiles, exposing personal information or even altering user privileges.

Scenario 3: An attacker exploits a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in a user profile page to inject a malicious script. When any user visits the infected profile, the script redirects them to a phishing site controlled by the attacker, aiming to steal their credentials.

To mitigate such threats, organizations should employ rigorous input validation, implement content security policies, regularly update and patch software components, and educate users on secure practices.

    2. Regularly review threat analytics reports to understand emerging threats and top security incidents affecting Dynamics 365 endpoints.
  6. Conduct Security Audits and Enhance Compliance:
    1. Perform routine security audits via Microsoft Compliance Center to ensure compliance with organizational and regulatory standards.
    2. Use audit logs to trace any suspicious activities and ensure the integrity of Dynamics 365 user actions and data access.

To enhance the security posture of Microsoft Dynamics 365, implementing encryption for sensitive data both at rest and in transit is crucial. Azure offers a range of encryption services to safeguard your data. Follow these steps to ensure effective encryption using Azure's tools and practices:

Step 1: Encrypt Data at Rest

  1. Leverage Azure Storage Service Encryption (SSE): Ensure that all data stored within Azure services is automatically encrypted using Azure Storage Service Encryption. This feature uses 256-bit AES encryption to secure data at rest.

    • Go to your Azure portal and navigate to the storage account used by Dynamics 365.
    • Select "Encryption" under the settings section.
    • Ensure that the "Blob service" and "File service" are set to enhance encryption. Azure SSE is enabled by default, but it's important to verify.

  2. Use Azure Key Vault for Key Management: Azure Key Vault helps manage and control access to encryption keys used by Azure services.

    • Create a new Key Vault in your Azure portal if you haven't already.
    • Store your encryption keys in Azure Key Vault and configure access policies to restrict and monitor access to these keys.
    • Integrate Azure Key Vault with Dynamics 365 by configuring your applications to use keys from the vault for encrypting and decrypting data.

Step 2: Encrypt Data in Transit

  1. Enable HTTPS for Dynamics 365: Always use HTTPS to encrypt data in transit between clients and Microsoft Dynamics 365.

    • Configure Dynamics 365 to enforce HTTPS connections by setting Appropriate Transport Security settings within the Dynamics 365 admin center.
    • Ensure any external systems or third-party integrations use HTTPS protocols to connect to Dynamics 365.

  2. Implement Azure ExpressRoute: Use Azure ExpressRoute for secure, private connections when integrating Dynamics 365 with other Azure services or on-premises environments, connecting via a dedicated, encrypted network link.

    • Choose an ExpressRoute circuit that fits your organization's needs in terms of bandwidth and locations.
    • Configure encryption protocols for the ExpressRoute connection to ensure data confidentiality and integrity.

By following these procedures, organizations can substantially enhance the security of sensitive data within Microsoft Dynamics 365, ensuring robust protection against unauthorized access and data breaches.

To effectively secure sensitive information within Microsoft Dynamics 365, it is crucial to implement Data Loss Prevention (DLP) policies using the Microsoft 365 Security and Compliance Center. This approach helps in monitoring and preventing confidential data from being unintentionally shared both within and outside the organization. The following steps outline the process to configure these DLP policies:

  1. Access the Microsoft 365 Security and Compliance Center:
    1. Log in to your Microsoft 365 account using an administrative role.
    2. Navigate to the Microsoft 365 Security and Compliance Center.
  2. Navigate to the Data Loss Prevention Section:
    1. In the left-hand menu, click on "Policies." Then, select "Data Loss Prevention" under the "Data" category.
  3. Create a New DLP Policy:
    1. Click on the "+ Create policy" button to begin the process of setting up a new DLP policy.
    2. You will be prompted to choose a template. You can select a pre-configured template that fits your organizations needs (e.g., finance, health records) or create a custom policy.
  4. Configure Policy Settings:
    1. Specify the locations you want the DLP policy to cover. This can include Exchange email, SharePoint sites, OneDrive accounts, and Microsoft Teams conversations.
    2. Define the conditions that trigger the policy, such as specific types of information (e.g., credit card numbers, social security numbers).
    3. Set the desired actions for when a policy is violated. Options can include blocking content transmission, encrypting emails, or notifying users.
  5. Test and Implement the Policy:
    1. Before full deployment, it is advisable to run the policy in audit mode to analyze its impact without enforcing it.
    2. Once satisfied with the testing phase, enforce the policy to make it active across the selected environments.
  6. Monitor and Review:
    1. After the policy is live, continuously monitor its performance via compliance reports available in the Security and Compliance Center.
    2. Regularly review and update the policy to adapt to new business requirements and regulatory changes.

Implementing these steps will help ensure that sensitive data within Microsoft Dynamics 365 is protected against unauthorized sharing, thereby maintaining compliance and minimizing risks to the organization.

countermeasure.name: Implement multi-factor authentication
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of Microsoft Dynamics 365, it is crucial to enable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for all user accounts. MFA requires users to provide multiple forms of verification before access is granted, thereby strengthening the security posture by ensuring that access requires both something the user knows, like a password, and something the user has, such as a security token.

Follow these steps to configure MFA using Microsoft Entra (Azure Active Directory):

  1. Accessing Azure Portal:
    • Log in to the Azure Portal using your administrator credentials.
  2. Navigating to Azure Active Directory:
    • In the Azure Portal, select Azure Active Directory from the left-hand navigation pane.
  3. Configuring Conditional Access Policies:
    • Under the Azure Active Directory section, click on Security and then select Conditional Access.
    • Click on + New policy to create a new policy for MFA.
    • Name the policy descriptively, such as Require MFA for Dynamics 365 Access.
  4. Defining Assignments:
    • Under Users and groups, select the user groups to which the policy will apply. To ensure maximum security, include all users who access Dynamics 365.

countermeasure.name: Utilize conditional access policies
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of Microsoft Dynamics 365, configuring conditional access policies using Microsoft Entra can effectively control access based on user, location, device, and risk factors. Implementing these controls ensures that only trusted users in appropriate scenarios can access your Dynamics 365 environment. Below is a step-by-step guide to set up these policies:

  1. Sign in to Azure Portal:
    • Open your web browser and navigate to the Azure Portal.
    • Use your Microsoft Entra administrator credentials to sign in.
  2. Access Microsoft Entra ID:
    • In the left navigation pane, select Azure Active Directory.
  3. Navigate to Conditional Access:
    • Under the Security menu, select Conditional Access.
    • Click on + New policy to create a new policy.
  4. Define the Policy Name and Assignments:
    • Enter a meaningful name for the policy.
    • Under Assignments, define the Users or workload identities affected by this policy. You may choose specific users, groups, or directory roles.
  5. Configure Cloud Apps or Actions:
    • Under Cloud apps or actions, select Select apps and choose Microsoft Dynamics 365 from the list.
  6. Set Conditions:
    • Under Conditions, configure the conditions under which access controls are applied:
      • Sign-in risk: Decide if additional authentication is needed for sign-ins with a particular risk level.
      • Locations: Specify access restrictions based on trusted and untrusted locations, such as specific IP addresses and geographical areas.
      • Devices: Define requirements for device compliance or trusted device types.
  7. Configure Access Controls:
    • Under Access controls, configure both grant and session controls:
      • Grant: Choose one or more controls, such as requiring multi-factor authentication, compliance with device settings, or use of specific user credentials.
      • Session: You may customize sessions for the user, ensuring ongoing evaluations of the activity based on policies.
  8. Enable and Monitor the Policy:
    • Select Enable policy to activate the conditional access policy.
    • Monitor the effectiveness by reviewing the Sign-ins logs under Monitoring in Azure Active Directory to ensure that the policy is functioning as intended.

threat.name: Unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized data access in Microsoft Power BI occurs when individuals gain access to reports, dashboards, or datasets without proper authorization. This can result from weak access controls, misconfigured sharing settings, or compromised accounts, leading to the exposure of sensitive business information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploit weak authentication or compromised accounts to access Power BI resources.
  • Insiders: Malicious or negligent employees accessing data beyond their role or need.
  • Misconfigured Permissions: Overly permissive or incorrect access configurations expose data to unauthorized users.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Exposure of confidential information such as financial reports or customer data.
  • Compliance Failures: Violations of data protection regulations like GDPR or HIPAA.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer and partner trust due to mishandling of sensitive information.
  • Financial Losses: Costs related to incident remediation, fines, and potential lawsuits.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Account Access: An attacker uses stolen credentials to access a Power BI workspace containing sensitive sales data.
  2. Excessive Permissions Misuse: An internal user with access to all datasets views confidential HR data they are not authorized to see.
  3. Misconfigured Sharing: A Power BI report containing proprietary analytics is shared with external users due to improperly configured sharing settings.

threat.name: Data leakage through sharing
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data leakage through sharing occurs when sensitive Power BI reports or dashboards are shared with unauthorized users due to improper sharing configurations. This can result in the exposure of confidential or sensitive business information, violating privacy regulations and damaging organizational trust.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Users: Employees or contractors accidentally or intentionally sharing data with unauthorized recipients.
  • External Attackers: Exploiting overly permissive sharing settings to gain access to shared data.
  • Misconfigured Settings: Inadequate controls over sharing permissions, leading to unintended data exposure.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Confidential business information is accessed by unauthorized users.
  • Compliance Violations: Breaches of data protection regulations such as GDPR or HIPAA.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust from customers and partners due to exposed sensitive data.
  • Financial Losses: Costs associated with incident response, legal penalties, and remediation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unintended Sharing with External Users: An employee accidentally shares a report containing financial data with an external email address, exposing the organizations internal financial performance.
  2. Exploiting Public Links: An attacker gains access to a publicly shared Power BI dashboard that contains sensitive customer data due to improper access restrictions.
  3. Unauthorized Forwarding: An internal user forwards a shared link to a Power BI report to an unauthorized party, granting them access to sensitive information.

threat.name: Insecure data storage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure data storage in Microsoft Power BI refers to sensitive data being stored without proper encryption or access controls. This can result in unauthorized access to critical business information, exposing the organization to data breaches, compliance violations, and reputational damage.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploit weak encryption or misconfigured storage to access sensitive data.
  • Insiders: Employees or contractors accessing unprotected data without proper authorization.
  • Misconfigured Systems: Improper setup of Power BI storage settings, leaving data unencrypted or accessible to unauthorized users.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Exposure of sensitive data such as financial reports, customer details, or proprietary analytics.
  • Compliance Failures: Violations of regulations like GDPR, CCPA, or HIPAA due to improper data protection.
  • Operational Disruptions: Alteration or corruption of unprotected data, affecting business decision-making.
  • Financial Losses: Costs associated with legal penalties, remediation, and loss of business.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unencrypted Storage Access: An attacker exploits weak security on Power BI storage and retrieves customer data that was not encrypted.
  2. Improper File Permissions: An internal user accesses confidential financial reports stored in Power BI due to misconfigured access controls.
  3. Data Exfiltration via Misconfigured Backup: Backup copies of Power BI reports stored in an unprotected location are accessed and exfiltrated by an unauthorized user.

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring and auditing
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insufficient monitoring and auditing in Microsoft Power BI refers to a lack of visibility into user activities, access patterns, and data interactions. This absence of oversight makes it difficult to detect unauthorized access, suspicious behaviors, or data misuse, increasing the risk of prolonged exposure to security threats.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploit the lack of monitoring to perform unauthorized actions undetected.
  • Insiders: Malicious or negligent employees misuse their access without being flagged.
  • Compromised Accounts: Hijacked accounts perform malicious actions without triggering alerts.

Impacts

  • Undetected Data Breaches: Prolonged unauthorized access to sensitive reports or dashboards.
  • Compliance Violations: Failure to meet regulatory requirements for activity tracking and reporting.
  • Operational Risks: Missed opportunities to identify and respond to anomalies, leading to data misuse or loss.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust due to delayed responses to security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Undetected Unauthorized Access: An attacker gains access to a Power BI workspace using compromised credentials and exfiltrates sensitive reports without being detected due to lack of activity monitoring.
  2. Data Misuse by Insider: An employee with access to confidential dashboards downloads sensitive data and shares it externally without triggering any alerts.
  3. Delayed Breach Detection: Suspicious login attempts are ignored because audit logs are not enabled or monitored, allowing attackers to persist in the environment.

weakness.name: CWE-242
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-242: Use of Inherently Dangerous Function The product calls a function that can never be guaranteed to work safely. Certain functions behave in dangerous ways regardless of how they are used. Functions in this category were often implemented without taking security concerns into account. The gets() function is unsafe because it does not perform bounds checking on the size of its input. An attacker can easily send arbitrarily-sized input to gets() and overflow the destination buffer. Similarly, the >> operator is unsafe to use when reading into a statically-allocated character array because it does not perform bounds checking on the size of its input. An attacker can easily send arbitrarily-sized input to the >> operator and overflow the destination buffer.

weakness.name: CWE-281
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-281: Improper Preservation of Permissions The product does not preserve permissions or incorrectly preserves permissions when copying, restoring, or sharing objects, which can cause them to have less restrictive permissions than intended.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-353
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-353: Missing Support for Integrity Check The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum. If integrity check values or "checksums" are omitted from a protocol, there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications, the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum, since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages, as opposed to single packets.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-415
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-415: Double Free The product calls free() twice on the same memory address, potentially leading to modification of unexpected memory locations. When a program calls free() twice with the same argument, the program's memory management data structures become corrupted. This corruption can cause the program to crash or, in some circumstances, cause two later calls to malloc() to return the same pointer. If malloc() returns the same value twice and the program later gives the attacker control over the data that is written into this doubly-allocated memory, the program becomes vulnerable to a buffer overflow attack.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-610
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-610: Externally Controlled Reference to a Resource in Another Sphere The product uses an externally controlled name or reference that resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-707
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-707: Improper Neutralization The product does not ensure or incorrectly ensures that structured messages or data are well-formed and that certain security properties are met before being read from an upstream component or sent to a downstream component.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Attach metadata and confidence per record
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the trustworthiness, quality, and auditability of your AI training data, as required by regulations like the EU AI Act, you must create a detailed, record-level lineage. This is achieved by designing your data curation pipeline to stamp every individual record with rich metadata as it is processed. This metadata provides a verifiable trail of a record's origin, the transformations applied to it, and its quality score, which is critical for security forensics, debugging bias, and proving compliance.

A data or MLOps engineer should implement this by architecting the pipeline in the following way:

  1. Design an Enriched Data Schema:
    • The schema for your curated datasets must include a dedicated field or nested object (e.g., _metadata) to store this provenance information.
  2. Stamp Metadata at Each Pipeline Stage:
    • Your automated data curation pipeline (e.g., in Azure Data Factory or Databricks) must be composed of discrete stages, with each stage adding or updating the metadata for every record it processes.
    • Ingestion Stage: This stage must add metadata about the data's origin, such as source_system and ingestion_timestamp.
    • Cleaning Stage: This stage must append the names and versions of any cleaning or sanitization functions applied, such as pii_redacted_v1.2.
    • Labeling Stage: If data is being labeled, this stage must add the label, the label_source (e.g., 'human_expert' or 'auto_label_model_v3'), and a label_confidence_score.
  3. Persist and Use the Enriched Data:
    • The final dataset produced by the pipeline, which is used for model training, must contain both the data and this complete metadata trail for every record. This allows you to easily trace, filter, or triage your training data based on its history.

References:

  • NIST AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF 1.0)
  • European Commission: The AI Act

countermeasure.name: Continuous testing and shadow pipelines
countermeasure.desc:
To protect your AI models and downstream systems from the effects of corrupted, insecure, or biased data, you must treat your data curation pipeline as a critical software asset. This requires implementing a rigorous "Continuous Integration for Data" (CI for Data) methodology. This control involves automated data quality testing to find and fix bugs in your transformation code before it is merged, and using shadow pipelines to safely validate a new pipeline version against live data without any risk to your production datasets.

A data or MLOps engineer should implement this by following these steps:

  1. Implement a CI Pipeline with Data Quality Tests:
    • All data transformation code must be managed in a version-controlled Git repository with a mandatory pull request (PR) process.
    • Your CI pipeline (e.g., in Azure Pipelines) must automatically run a suite of data quality and expectation tests on every PR.
    • Use a dedicated framework like Great Expectations to create testable assertions about your data (e.g., expect_column_values_to_not_be_null, expect_column_to_match_regex). The PR must be blocked if these tests fail.
  2. Deploy New Pipeline Versions in Shadow Mode:
    • After passing CI, a new pipeline version (v2) must be deployed in a shadow mode.
    • This involves running the v2 pipeline in parallel with the current production pipeline (v1), with both processing the same stream of live, raw data.
  3. Isolate and Compare Outputs:
    • The output of the stable v1 pipeline continues to feed downstream production systems. The output of the shadow v2 pipeline must be written to a separate, isolated storage location.
    • You must have an automated reconciliation job that compares the outputs from v1 and v2, checking for any unexpected discrepancies in record counts, schema, or the statistical distribution of the data.
  4. Promote or Discard the Shadow Pipeline:
    • The v2 pipeline can only be promoted to become the new primary production pipeline after the reconciliation job confirms its output is correct and consistent.
    • If the reconciliation finds significant issues, it must trigger an alert, and the v2 pipeline must be decommissioned and the issue fixed in development.

References:

  • Great Expectations - A data quality framework
  • Martin Fowler: Parallel Run (Shadow Pipeline Pattern)

countermeasure.name: Control dependencies and use allowlists
countermeasure.desc:
To protect your data curation pipeline from software supply chain attacks, you must strictly control all third-party software dependencies (e.g., from PyPI, Maven). You must move from an unmanaged model of pulling packages directly from the internet to a secure allowlist model. This is achieved by using a private package repository, like Azure Artifacts, which contains only the specific library versions that have been vetted for security vulnerabilities and license compliance.

A DevSecOps or platform engineer should implement this by following these steps:

  1. Establish a Vetting and Approval Process:
    • You must have a formal process for developers to request and get approval for new open-source libraries. This process must include automated Software Composition Analysis (SCA) to check for known vulnerabilities and a review of the package's license.
  2. Implement a Private, Curated Repository:
    • You must deploy and configure a private package repository using a service like Azure Artifacts.
    • This repository should be configured to act as a proxy or to host only the specific, approved versions of the libraries from your allowlist.
  3. Configure All Runtimes to Use the Private Repository:
    • The compute environments where your pipeline jobs execute (e.g., CI/CD agents, Databricks clusters) must be configured to resolve and download dependencies only from your private Azure Artifacts feed.
  4. Block Direct Access to Public Repositories:
    • As a critical, non-bypassable enforcement mechanism, you must configure network egress controls for your compute environments.

countermeasure.name: Human-in-the-loop with automated sampling
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure your AI systems are trained on high-quality, accurate, and fair data, as required by regulations like the EU AI Act, a fully automated curation pipeline is insufficient. You must implement a risk-based, human-in-the-loop (HITL) review process. This involves using intelligent sampling algorithms to select the most uncertain, risky, or anomalous data points from your pipeline and routing them to subject matter experts for manual validation and correction. This creates a crucial feedback loop that improves data quality and protects against subtle data poisoning attacks.

A data science or MLOps team should implement this by following these steps:

  1. Implement a Risk-Based Sampling Step:
    • After data has been automatically processed or labeled, you must have an automated step that selects a subset of records for human review. This is not a random sample.
    • The sampling algorithm must be risk-based, prioritizing records that are most likely to be incorrect or malicious. This includes records where:
      • The automated labeling model had a low confidence score.
      • The data point is a statistical outlier compared to the rest of the dataset.
      • An active learning strategy identifies the record as being highly informative or uncertain.
  2. Utilize a Managed Data Labeling Service:
    • The sampled data must be routed to a dedicated data labeling project to manage the human review workflow.
    • In Azure, the recommended service is Azure Machine Learning data labeling, which provides the interface for human annotators to efficiently review and correct data.
  3. Establish a Feedback Loop for Continuous Improvement:
    • The results of the human review (the corrected labels) form a high-quality, "golden" dataset.
    • This dataset must be used to augment your final training set.
    • Crucially, this dataset must also be used to periodically retrain and improve the automated labeling model itself, making your data curation pipeline smarter and more efficient over time.

References:

  • European Commission: The AI Act

countermeasure.name: Isolate execution environment and restrict egress
countermeasure.desc:
To prevent data exfiltration and contain the impact of a potential compromise within your data pipeline, you must execute all data curation jobs in a strongly isolated execution environment. This requires a zero-trust network model. The pipeline's compute resources must be deployed into a private virtual network (VNet), and all outbound network connections must be forced through a central firewall that enforces a deny-by-default egress policy.

A cloud security or DevOps engineer should implement this by architecting the following network controls:

  1. Deploy Compute into a Dedicated VNet (VNet Injection):
    • The compute resources for your data curation pipeline (e.g., an Azure Databricks workspace or Azure Synapse workspace) must be deployed into a dedicated, private virtual network. Public-facing deployments for data processing are prohibited.
  2. Implement a Deny-All Default Egress Policy:
    • The subnets hosting the data curation compute must have a Network Security Group (NSG) applied that includes a low-priority rule to deny all outbound traffic to the Internet service tag.
  3. Route All Egress Traffic Through a Central Firewall:
    • You must apply a User-Defined Route (UDR) to the compute subnets that directs all default outbound traffic (0.0.0.0/0) to the private IP address of your central Azure Firewall.
  4. Create a Granular FQDN Allowlist:
    • In the Azure Firewall, you must create Application Rules that constitute a strict allowlist.
    • These rules must permit outbound HTTPS traffic only to the specific, fully qualified domain names (FQDNs) that the pipeline is authorized to contact (e.g., your Azure Data Lake Storage endpoint, a specific source data API, or a private package repository). All other outbound traffic will be blocked and logged.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-207 - Zero Trust Architecture

countermeasure.name: Minimize and mask PII
countermeasure.desc:
To comply with the core principles of GDPR, such as "data minimization" and "pseudonymisation," you must ensure that raw Personally Identifiable Information (PII) is removed from your datasets as early as possible. This requires a mandatory scrubbing and pseudonymization stage in your data curation pipeline. This automated process is a critical control for protecting user privacy by removing all unnecessary PII and transforming the remaining, essential PII into a non-identifiable, tokenized format before the data is used for analytics or model training.

A data engineer should implement this by architecting the following pipeline stage:

  1. Enforce Feature Minimization:
    • As a first step, the pipeline must drop any columns containing PII that are not absolutely essential for the downstream use case. This decision should be documented as part of your data governance process.
  2. Detect and Redact PII in Unstructured Text:
    • For free-text fields, the pipeline must use a service like the PII detection feature of Azure AI Language.
    • Based on the service's output, the pipeline must redact (mask) the identified PII, replacing it with generic placeholders (e.g., [PERSON], [PHONE_NUMBER]).
  3. Pseudonymize Key Identifiers:
    • For identifier fields that must be retained for analysis (like a CustomerID), the pipeline must replace the real values with a consistent pseudonym or token.
    • This should be implemented using a strong, salted hashing algorithm (e.g., HMAC-SHA256). The secret salt key must be stored securely in Azure Key Vault.
  4. Use Only Cleansed Data Downstream:
    • The output of this stage must be a new, fully sanitized dataset. All subsequent pipeline stages, including the final model training job, must only be granted access to this cleansed version. Access to the original, raw data must be highly restricted and subject to a short retention policy.

References:

  • GDPR, Article 5 - Principles relating to processing of personal data
